description: From Middle English expense, from Anglo-Norman expense and Old French espense, from Late Latin expēnsa, from Latin expendō. See expend.

entries.meaning: A spending or consuming, often a disbursement of funds.
examples: She went to great expense to ensure her children would get the best education.
Buying the car was a big expense, but will be worth it in the long run.
We had a training weekend in New York, at the expense of our company.

entries.meaning: The elimination or consumption of something, sometimes with the notion of loss or damage to the thing eliminated.
examples: Jones reached the final at the expense of Smith, who couldn't beat him.

verbs.description: expense (third-person singular simple present expenses, present participle expensing, simple past and past participle expensed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To charge a cost against an expense account; to bill something to the company for which one works.
examples: It should be acceptable to expense a business lunch with a client.
